_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: High winds, Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Change from Program Level 2 to Program Level 3
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Railcars inspected in accordance with the PSM Railcar Operating Procedures
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Boettcher Landing Facility Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 1 (i.e. Railcar Storage) equipment may include up to nine 34,000-gallon railcars.  TMC does not own the railcars and therefore is not responsible for the mechanical integrity of the railcar.  However, trained TMC personnel receive, inspect, and release railcars in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Railcar Operating Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in the Railcar Operating Procedures.  Transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the railcars to the storage tanks and from the storage tanks to NH3 Semi Trucks is considered to be part of Covered Process 2 (i.e. Storage and Handling ? Anhydrous Ammonia).

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: High Winds, Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Changed from Program Level 2 to Program Level 3
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks, process piping, pumps, compressors, valves, etc...
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The McGregor Company (TMC) Boettcher Landing Facility Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained TMC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 2 (i.e. Storage and Handling ? Anhydrous Ammonia) equipment includes three stationary storage tanks (i.e. two 30,000-gallon and one 25,949-gallon), two vapor compressor tanks, and ancillary liquid pumps, gas compressors, piping, and valves.  As described in Covered Process 1, the Facility receives bulk shipments of anhydrous ammonia by railcar.  As part of Covered Process 2, Facility Process Operators transfer the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar(s) to the three stationary storage tanks and then they transfer the anhydrous ammonia from the stationary storage tanks to NH3 Semi Trucks for transportation to the client location.  Trained TMC Process Operators perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia into and out of the stationary storage tanks in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Storage and Handling Operating Procedures.  Trained TMC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  TMC is responsible for training its personnel in these Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of The McGregor Company (TMC) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to the operations at the TMC Boettcher Landing Facility located at Central Ferry in Pomeroy, WA.  At this Facility, TMC engages in the distribution and sale of chemicals to customers, most of who use TMC's products to support agricultural operations.  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia from the Boettcher Landing Facility located approximately 24 miles north-northwest of Pomeroy, WA at 601 Central Ferry Road, Pomeroy, WA 99347.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Boettcher Landing Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Boettcher Landing Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



TMC is submitting this plan as a "Resubmission" of all applicable sections of the RMP.  Based on its analysis, TMC has revised this RMP to reflect 2 covered processes and has changed the RMP Program Level from 2 to 3.  All relevant sections for a Program 3 RMP Facility have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility PSM/RMPr.



FACILITY



The Operations at the Boettcher Landing Facility consists of agricultural chemical storage and handling and distribution.  As related to the PSM/RMPr, the Boettcher Landing Facility stores and

handles one covered chemical (anhydrous ammonia) at quantities that exceed the threshold quantity established by EPA, and operates two (2) covered processes that include:



o    Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage

o    Covered Process 2: Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and Handling



The Boettcher Landing Facility receives bulk quantities of anhydrous ammonia by railcar.  A total of nine (9) 34,000-gallon insulated railcars can be staged on the North and South Rail Spurs combined.  Trained Facility Process Operators transfer the anhydrous ammonia from the railcars to all three (3) storage stationary tanks for storage.  Two of the stationary storage tanks are 30,000 gallons and one is 25,949 gallons.  From the stationary storage tanks, the anhydrous ammonia may be transferred to NH3 Semi Truck(s) for transportation to the client location.  TMC trains all of its Process Operators and Maintenance Personnel in the relevant operating and maintenance procedures provided in the PSM/RMPr.    



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the two covered processes. The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released.  The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



Depending on the covered process, the alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes (1) the failure to fully close a vapor valve on a railcar (Covered Process 1), and (2) the failure of making a sealed connection of the loading arm to the NH3 Semi Truck.  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (excess flow devices and emergency shutoff valves) and operating procedures that TMC uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Boettcher La

nding Facility Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Boettcher Landing Facility Manager is assisted by other trained TMC staff, as directed.  The Boettcher Landing Facility Manager is responsible for ensuring that TMC Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



TMC's Boettcher Landing Facility is a non-responding facility. TMC has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Boettcher Landing Facility.









CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by The McGregor Company at the Boettcher Landing Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Boettcher Landing Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Whitman County LEPC and Pomeroy Fire Department.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, 6, and 8 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Boettcher Landing Facility.
